title: 113_s743
content: The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" authorizes the collection of sales and use taxes. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" allows Member States under the Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement to require sellers not qualifying for the small seller exception to collect and remit sales taxes for remote sales. States can exercise this authority 180 days after publishing notice, ensuring changes to the agreement do not conflict with simplification requirements. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" allows non-Member States to require sellers to collect and remit sales taxes for remote sales if they adopt minimum simplification requirements. States can start enforcing this authority at least 6 months after enacting legislation specifying the applicable taxes. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" allows non-Member States to require sellers to collect and remit sales taxes for remote sales if they adopt minimum simplification requirements. States can enforce this authority by specifying applicable taxes and implementing minimum simplification requirements for sales and use tax administration. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" allows remote sellers to undergo a single audit for all State and local taxing jurisdictions within the State. Remote sellers can use a single sales and use tax return to be filed with the entity responsible for tax administration. States cannot require remote sellers to file tax returns more frequently than nonremote sellers or impose additional requirements on them. Local jurisdictions cannot require remote sellers to submit tax returns or collect sales taxes beyond what is required for nonremote sellers. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" allows remote sellers to submit a uniform sales and use tax base, source all remote sales in compliance with sourcing definitions, and provide information on taxability of products and services. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" provides software for remote sellers to calculate and file sales and use taxes, certification procedures for software providers, and relieves remote sellers from liability. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" provides relief for remote sellers and certified software providers from liability for incorrect tax collection, remittance, or noncollection due to errors or misleading information. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" relieves remote sellers and certified software providers from liability for incorrect tax collection due to errors or misleading information. It also requires a 90-day notice of rate changes and updates to information provided by the State. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" provides a 90-day notice period for rate changes and updates to information. A State can only require a remote seller to collect sales taxes if their total remote sales exceed $1,000,000 in the previous year. Gross annual receipts from remote sales of related persons can be aggregated to meet the threshold. The rules state that individuals must comply with specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code to prevent avoidance of tax regulations through ownership relationships. The limitations outlined in Section 3 aim to prevent tax avoidance through ownership relationships. The Act does not subject sellers to various taxes other than sales and use taxes, does not affect tax application, and does not change state authority to impose taxes. It does not create nexus or change nexus standards, allows remote sellers to choose software providers, and does not impact state licensing or regulatory requirements. The Act does not affect state authority to regulate or tax businesses. It does not encourage new taxes or impact intrastate sales. States must comply with intrastate provisions of the Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement. States granted authority under section 2(a) must comply with intrastate provisions of the Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement. The Act does not affect the Mobile Telecommunications Sourcing Act. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS AND SPECIAL RULES. In this Act, a certified software provider is defined as a person who provides software to remote sellers for tax compliance and is certified by a State. The terms "locality" and "local" refer to any political subdivision of a State. A Member State is defined as a state under the Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement, excluding associate members. The term "person" includes various legal entities and governments. A "remote sale" refers to a sale into a State where the seller is not required to pay taxes unless specified by this Act. A "remote seller" is a person making remote sales in the State. A remote seller is defined as a person making remote sales in the State. The location to which a remote sale is sourced is where the product or service is received by the purchaser, based on delivery instructions provided by the purchaser. If no delivery location is specified, the sale is sourced to the customer's known address or obtained during the transaction. If no address is available, the sale is sourced to the customer's payment instrument address. The term "State" includes various territories and tribal organizations. State authorities must comply with sourcing provisions of the Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement. The term "Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement" refers to a multi-State agreement adopted on November 12, 2002, and further amended from time to time. SEC. 5. SEVERABILITY. If any provision of this Act is deemed unconstitutional, the rest of the Act remains unaffected. SEC. 6. PREEMPTION. This Act does not limit any powers of State or local jurisdictions unless specified.
